colour.translation[0].definitions[0].def: red, blue, yellow, green, brown, purple etc
colour.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: What colour dress did you buy?
The pens come in a wide range of colours.
The walls were a lovely reddish-brown color.
colour.translation[0].definitions[1].def: the appearance of something as a result of the way it reflects (=throws back) light, especially when its appearance is very bright or is made up of a lot of different colours
colour.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: Bright bold accessories are the quickest way to add colour to a room.
a splash of colour (=a small area of a bright colour)
The sky began to slowly change colour.
the fall colors  (=the colours of the trees in autumn)
In summer the gardens are a blaze of colour.
The wine was almost pink in colour  (=was almost pink).
colour.translation[0].definitions[2].def: how dark or light someone’s skin is, which shows which race they belong to
colour.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: Everyone has a right to a job, regardless of their race, sex, or colour.
the continuing battle against colour prejudice
colour.translation[0].definitions[3].def: a substance such as paint or dye that makes something red, blue, yellow etc
colour.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: Wash the garment separately, as the colour may run (=come out when washed).
jams that contain no artificial colours or preservatives
our new range of eyeshadows and lip colours
colour.translation[0].definitions[4].def: if you have some colour in your face, your face is pink or red, usually because you are healthy or embarrassed
colour.translation[0].definitions[4].exa: You look a lot better today. At least you’ve got a bit of colour now.
One of the girls giggled nervously as colour flooded her cheeks (=her cheeks suddenly went very pink or red).
He stared at her, the colour draining from his face.
colour.translation[0].definitions[5].def: interesting and exciting details or qualities that someone or something has
colour.translation[0].definitions[5].exa: The old market is lively, full of colour and activity.
a travel writer in search of local colour
Intelligent use of metaphors can add colour to your writing.
colour.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: Our door was painted a bright green colour.
The glass used for bottles is often a greenish colour.
Bright colours look good in strong sunlight.
His paintings are known for their use of bold colours.
I love the rich colours in oriental rugs.
People tend to wear dark colours to work.
Light colours make a room look larger.
The old farmhouse is beautifully decorated with warm colours.
Italian sweaters come in lovely subtle colours.
You need to have one or two contrasting colours in the room.
Plant the flowers in patches in complementary colours.
I bought some gloves and a scarf in a matching colour.
Why are children’s toys always in primary colours?
The colour in this tin of paint doesn’t match the walls.
Do you think the colour of this tie clashes with my shirt?
The colour of the curtains had faded in the sun.
Have you decided on a colour scheme?
In autumn the leaves create lovely colour combinations.
There’s a wide colour range to choose from.
colour.translation[0].note_box[1].sectio: red, blue, yellow etc
Blue is my favourite colour.
Matisse was famous for his use of colour.
shade
a particular type of a colour
The dress is a light shade of pink.
He uses different shades of green.
hue
a particular colour or shade of a colour
Her face had lost its golden hue.
tint
a small amount of a colour in something that is mostly another colour
He wears sunglasses that have a pinky-orange tint.
tone
one of the many different shades of a colour, each slightly darker, lighter, brighter etc than the next
Carpets in neutral tones give a feeling of space.
dark colours
used about a colour that is strong and fairly close to black
a dark blue suit
His eyes are dark brown.
fairly dark – often used when you think this colour looks attractive
His eyes were a beautiful deep blue.
deep red lips
rich
used about a colour that is fairly dark in a way that gives a pleasant feeling of warmth
The walls were painted a rich red colour.
light colours
used about a colour that is not dark
a light blue sweater
His T-shirt was light green.
pale
used about a colour that is very light
He has very pale blue eyes.
used about a colour that is light in a way that is attractive because it is not too obvious
She wears soft colours such as cream, which match her complexion.
pastel
used about a colour that has a lot of white in it
The girls wore pastel pink sundresses.
bright colours
used about a colour that is strong and easy to see
The front door was painted bright red.
brilliant/vivid
used about a colour that is very bright
I looked out at the brilliant blue sky.
vivid red flowers
colourful
used about things that have many different bright colours
There were window boxes full of colourful flowers.
multicoloured
used about things that have a pattern of many different bright colours
A multicoloured flag waved in the midday sun.
gaudy/garish
too brightly coloured, in a way that is unattractive
The wallpaper was much too gaudy for me.
a garish orange tie
colour.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to change the colour of something, especially by using dye
colour.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: If I didn’t colour my hair I’d be totally grey.
Colour the icing with a little green food colouring.
Sunset came and coloured the sky a brilliant red.
colour.translation[1].definitions[1].def: to use coloured pencils to put colours inside the lines of a picture
colour.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: On the back page is a picture for your child to colour in.
She has no idea how to colour a picture – she just scribbles all over it.
colour.translation[1].definitions[2].def: when someone colours, their face becomes redder because they are embarrassed
colour.translation[1].definitions[2].exa: Her eyes suddenly met his and she coloured slightly.
